text: Tracy Sohl: Great question -- and timely, since abolitionist vegans (and some media outlets, hello Grauniad) have been pushing livestock as a major cause of climate warming. Sorry, Leo but cows etc, are only a minor cause because -- as with trees -- cows etc. are part of the short-term C cycle. 100% of cow carbon was recently in the air, since cows obtain all of it from plants. This is very different from what we are doing by taking carbon from underground and putting it in the air, a massive geophysical experiment that the ocean and terrestrial biosphere can only mitigate up to a point. Changing diets and planting trees helps somewhat -- but it does not address the root problem: burning carbon that would otherwise stay unburned underground for a very, very long time.

text:
@TheGandorX  Sun drives the climate over periods of over 10,000; 40,000 & 120,000. More information can be found by looking up Milankovitch's theory. It has been proven with glacier core data and other sources of historical climate data (tree cores, corals, isotopic oxygen). This alone can provide you significant scientific evidence that man-made (anthropogenic) climate change is driven by GHG emissions.

The carbon cycle creates the 'thermostat' of the planet. Although that, as well as the sun's climate regulation, occurs over thousands of years. Completed through a processes of chemical and physical weathering. Of which actually take even longer than the sun cycles. Keeping this in mind, we do not possess sufficient time to allow nature to reverse our impacts on the climate.

text: All plants are adapted to reflect heat, they are like space blankets in this respect, they are a huge factor in reflecting solar heat back out into space, the loss of forests negatively impacts the planets albedo, but so too does the loss of grasslands.  Grasslands are decimated by goats and sheep, which graze down to the root, killing the plant. By contrast other livestock is softer on the land.  Goats cause desertification. Without ground cover from small grasses, soils bake in the sun, and don’t retain moisture, the water table suffers, rivers and springs dry up, and aquifers don’t get replenished.  Goat and sheep management is absolutely critical!!!!!!!  The introduction of bison has even been found to exponentially reinvigorate grassland ecosystems.  Soil health is also key to all of this.  Soil health is the key metric around which we can gauge policy effects, and mitigation strategies.  Bugs are crucial too, we need to be very sparing in the use of insecticides.

text:
1. It is known how to manually plant a polyculture of native diversity or a diversity of what will take, keeping in mind the natural spacing per species & given rapidity of climate changes. 
2. Mycorrhize roots from as local a source as possible, or specific to that species.
3. Start planting outward from extant forests & where they were most recently cut down. 
4. Plant hillsides & mountain slopes for the piling up of transpiration into rainclouds. That will restore nature's hydrology.  
5. Reforest down to the coasts to capture & sequester carbon, preventing it from slipping into the oceans, one of the best things we can do to aid ocean recovery.
6. Forests are known to be best at stabilizing climate and what we face is climate chaos, so this labour intensive mass action is integral to all that's needed to restore fertility, needed to grow food & for food to grow for wildlife.
7. Forests are a therapeutic setting & for e.g. conifer terpenes are known to boost immunity. 
8. You can still keep lumber flowing while ending clearcut logging & starting selection logging, preferably with horses that fertilize while making skid trails. This is real forest management, thinning the forest where too dense, not highgrading. Done in the spirit of stewardship will yield the rest of forest bounty, including foods, medicines, dyes, fibres, latex. Please advocate for this so we can forge a future for posterity.

text:
No, the climate activists at the UN never tell you 3 things: 
1. The earth is supersaturated with respect to the spectral absorption of water vapor and CO2, so any additional CO2 is not going to make a difference--we're already at 100% spectral absorption, and
2. The estimation variance of the General Circulation Model used by "climate scientists" working in league with the UN to predict the earth's climate overwhelms the estimate, rendering the models useless and criminally suspect!  Redistribution and control are the UN's objectives.
3. CO2 only makes up 1% of the greenhouse gasses in the atmosphere but the UN and their "climate scientists" don't want you to know that, or you'll question their conclusions about CO2.
And you should not only question their conclusions, but seriously doubt them.

text: I think your point is that mature forests store little to no additional carbon each year -- some trees die, releasing carbon, others grow, absorbing carbon, and the system as a whole is essentially in equilibrium.  However, the forest stores the carbon that is embodied in the trees.  For easy figuring, start with an estimate of on the order of a metric ton per hectare -- with wide variation (cf. boreal vs. rainforest).  Consequently, a mature forest stores a great deal of carbon.

text:
'leaving the land' to its own devices is ok if you have ample rainfall(which explains the ease  Ms. Tree achieved success), and if there was enough humus and organic detritus(microbial-fungal stuff admixed with organic matter that holds soil together and retains moisture). In foggy overcast areas of the UK, which is most of the UK, letting moss grow  will do the trick for starters.. 

 Desertified land in low-rainfall areas is difficult to re-forest because not many species can tolerate arid, baked earth. Some sort of monoculture, or oligoculture using drought-tolerant/heat-tolerant/pest-free and long-lived species is the way to go to build up humus and leaf litter, then introduce other trees as the soil gets enriched.

In cool climates like Ireland grasses have a lot more carbon sequestration because grasses pump sugars into the soil which create humates. Humates store soil carbon for a lot longer than tree humus from its litter. Soil carbon gets forgotten in a tree centric world in most cases because we are still arguing about how to calculate it. 
Once you go to the humid tropics and subtropics forests become the better carbon sequester. And in those areas we should look at making biochar based soils for our agriculture.

text:
A better idea might be to put a tax on the carbon emissions of each sector of the economy. Ideally it should be in the hands of the UN and every country would have to pay an equivalent carbon tax. The money then could be spent on four areas.
1) Development and implementation of renewable energy sources and backups, primarily focused on helping developing countries first.
2) Reforestation, again with the primary area being in developing countries with the goal of lifting people out of poverty.
3) Preventing deforestation,  encouraging recycling of metals and development/implementation of environmentally friendly forms of mining.
4) Encouraging people to transition to a vegan diet, to walk and cycle more, to contribute to tree planting charities that promote heterogeneous tree plantations and help poor people out of poverty.

text:
Replanting forests and woodlands not only captures carbon, but builds deep soil layers. Currently, much current agricultural land is so exhausted, thin, and often washed away by floods, there's only an estimated 30 harvests left (especially in Europe). 
If we want to continue farming the way we do (because, let's face it, permaculture is far too labour intensive for mass production of food), humans will need to 'rotate' agricultural land with established forests over a 'very, very long-term' system, leaving forests intact for 1-2 centuries to build and enrich soils in one place, while intensive farming depletes soil as usual elsewhere. 
However, because of our constant greed for resources and our needless waste, we are both depleting agricultural soil 'and' ancient forested land at the same time. Eventually, we are going to come to the point where we haven't had newly-planted forests and woodlands established for long enough to build sufficient soil levels for future farming purposes. Soil that has been seriously over-grazed (and there's plenty of areas like that in Britain) takes well over a decade to recover even a couple of inches of soil depth if left fallow.

text:
Don't be fooled.    It's not the trees but the SOIL that will solve most of our climate woes.   The root systems sequester carbon where we need it,  in the soil.   More soil carbon is what would solve many flooding and drought issues,  while boosting harvests.  

If plantations are part of the way back to reforestation,  so be it.  They just need to work in other crops in these places,  including cover crops.

What would help is for ranchers to learn the benefit of appropriate trees.  1)  Specific varieties of trees could supplement grass ss livestock feed.   Specific varieties for particular types of animals is important.   2)  Trees are shade from hot weather-  too much heat stresses cattle and reduces weight gain.   3)  Trees provide wind protection for livestock.   4)  Trees protect grass from too much heat (grass doesn't grow in high heat).   5) Trees provide extra crops to increase the rancher's personal resiliency.  6) Trees as added food sources increase national security.  --Savannahs are the most productive types of land known.

Farmers need to interplant appropriate trees in their fields,  too.   1) Trees protect tenderer plants such as lettuce from heat stress, reducing the chance of bitterness.   2) Trees reduce topsoil erosion and reduce flood damage,  while  3)  The decay of stumps provides opportunities for growing crops like mushrooms.   4) Trees have the potential of increasing a farm's harvestable crops.  5)  Interplanting trees increase the farmer's personal resiliency.  

Shifting from plowing to no-till combined with several appropriate cover crops and interplanting trees,  combined with requiring countries like China to be an adult and cut its emmisions by a half (it's actually pretty readonable and doable would be all the effect needed to solve several issues with the recent depletion of soil carbon.   

The carbon from products like paper and agricultural wastes like rice husks can be made into agricultural charcoal and put back into the ground to increase its usefulness   Terra preta is carbon-rich soil that was deliberately by human activity.  Carbon-rich soil is called 'black gold'because most of the world's food crops grow best in this type of soil.

A few other simple strategies such as no-till farming,  cover cropping with several crops simultaneously,  getting a few crucial major polluter countries like China to cut their emissions by half (they aren't the economic weaklings they claim to be) would do all that' necessary to stop/significantly reduce the 'climate crisis' while also mitigating drought and flood damage.

text:
Very interesting.
When you think about what we're doing (on a grand scale) : we're taking carbon from underground and turning it into a greenhouse gas in our atmosphere. If a tree can take that greenhouse carbon gas and turn it back into solid carbon, we could take that solid carbon and push it back into the ground. To do this as efficiently as possible, you could plant a tree and wait for it to mature to a point where its rate of growth has slowed (turned a large amount of CO2 into solid carbon) and at that point, the tree could be turned into a *product that would be subsequently buried, effectively sinking your carbon in the same way that it was initially before we extracted it. You would then replant a tree and restart the process.

In this way, you wouldn't simply be using the land to carbon sink once, but to continuously sink carbon back where it was before we interfered with it. I'm aware that such a process of burying a solid tree deep into the ground isn't something that is done (we do with CO2 gas however) but what I'm saying is we should try to mimic what nature has done over millions of years and we'll need to do it more efficiently, using renewable resources of course. And this would need to be done along with a serious and meaningful reduction of our carbon greenhouse gas production to have the quickest effect.

So yes, I do think that planting trees is a necessity and a vital key to our future existence. It's what we do with a mature tree that would need to be rethought.

Just a thought.

text: A lot of the carbon in the atmosphere today  is originally from plant material that was buried and trapped during the Carboniferous period. They didn’t decompose and release the carbon back into the atmosphere, so they were effective carbon sinks. Trees can pull carbon out of the atmosphere but if they are allowed to decompose they won’t be more than temporary storage.  We’d have to harvest and bury or otherwise preserve dead trees to keep the carbon locked

text: stored? not quite. for a time, and that time can be quite short. the longest lasting use of a piece of timber would be to make high quality furniture or a violin/ cello out of it. The products then might last 100 years or more. But that's not what we do. We chip wood to make chipboard, and shave to make veneers and plywoods, and OSB.  They are not reusable. They get burned in a few years on average, and turnover is really high because of changing fashions, so rarely last past the next home refit in 10 to 15 years. In my country, UK, re-use of wood, even planed timber like flooring, is much lower than it was 50 years ago.

text:
Hi, though it looks kind of late to react, I'd like to share my thougts about the question : Isn't the problem of tree planting linked to the difference between the geological and atmospheric carbon cycle? We have brought a colossal amount of the first in the second thanks to the fossil energies, and to stop it to be stored under CO2 form, we hope trees may help us. The problem is, that to have the same amount or at leat a relatively sustainable level of CO2 with much more carbon in the atmospherical reservoir implies that a much, much larger part of carbon is stored under non-CO2 form in comparison with the pre-industrial era. A slight change of our societies makes this move more or less impossible : the world population has been multiplied by ten since, suffers less from hunger and has a plate share dominated by meat, wich requires lot of space to grow.
Also, the movement from atmoshere to geological stroring is slow, inexistant at our scale,wich means the solution as trees, stocking carbon in the atmospherical level are our only back-up, and when a forest is mature, it can't stock more. At the scale of the forest growth is hopefully a short scale in regard of what we desire to last, so this solution can only be provisory and with a limited impact, wich means : what about facing the problem we'll have to live with instead to flee ?

text: Forest gardening in layers can help. YouTube has a video with Robert Hart, from Shropshire, England, who did it and also wrote a book about it. On a large, small or even micro scale you can plant in layers with larger fruit trees, dwarf fruit trees, berry bushes/shrubs, then the ground cover layer with perennial vegetables and so on. It's inspired by forest gardens in India. Reduction and lifestyle changes and technology can assist this but the real shift must be the approach. Wilding is nice but it doesn't give you the food production and better density of forest gardening.

text: Trees are needed and urgently. Of course you do not throw a monoculture forest out there just to be decimated by the next pest or disease. Nor you just leave the land alone so deserts grow larger and forests take 200 years to develop on their own... What you do is you use a Permaculture approach, and with the right mix of multiple species and succession planting you get yourself in 10 years a young forest well on its way to producing new springs, creeks and natural ponds. Forests are 90% water, and they will store underground up to 15 times the amount of water they support on the surface. Their biomass allows us to enjoy up to 15°C less under the canopy on a hot day, act as insulation around our homes in the winter and evergreens protect our land from wind erosion. Trees are natural and efficient water pumps, as opposed to any artificial ones which end up lowering the water table and salinizing the soil. If we all understood these and the many more benefits of forests (e.g. wildlife and flora support, water condensation, climate regulation, air purification, soil improvement, energetic purification, food production) we wouldn't have a choice but to go out there and plant and hug trees, treat them with respect and give them many thanks for giving us all they do.

text:
Right but what you fail to mention is that the UK was once essentially fully forested aside from wetland areas...

Meadows, moorland, heathland, the open uplands. They're all man made habitats. Every single species that grows in these habitats will also grow under the cover of trees. Yet due to pressure from rich industries such as farming and shooting (in the uplands) the public are told misinformation. In that keeping these habitats free of trees we are increasing biodiversity. It's the biggest scandal in the country and one no one knows about it. Look at our uplands. They house only a handful of species. They can be described only as green deserts! If they were forested that wouldn't be the case.

But we keep these barren treeless landscapes such as moorland and heathland. This is not for the benefit of wildlife but of people.

If you look at tree planting from an ecological standpoint instead of a climate change one. Then it becomes quite clear that we owe it to our native species to reforest our land and bring it back to how it was when we first arrived. So no there is no problem with tree planting at all. The country naturally should be carpeted with trees. Pretty much all of our wildlife is adapted to a life in the forest. 

After all how can we lecture counties like Brazil and Indonesia to stop deforesting their land. When we here in the UK have already done it and out right refuse to reverse what we have done! All the while lecturing them on deforestation. It's laughable.

The problem with climate change starts with the economic and societal models underpinning the problem. All actions taken to turn back the clock is superficial. At present industry and especially the Western model of aggressive capitalism at all costs will offset all advances/progress made. Wouldn’t it be a better solution to regulate and evaluate industrial processes to meet environmental standards. 
Isolated Communities that have nothing to do with industrial and capitalist greed are paying the highest price for our current economic system/enslavement. Therein lies the teal tragedy. Just google Solomon Islands.
Amazing how the greed of a few impacts the lives of many. 
Shouldn’t environmental restitution be a universal human right. Shouldn’t we start taxing stock exchanges with an environmental levy on transactions or their profit as a solid start and start looking for an alternative monetary and banking system too?

text: You are spot. If all human beings were removed from the Terran equation, it would take centuries for the naturally formed forest cover to sink an amount of carbon equal to that released by the deforestation caused by the switch from hunting and gathering to agriculture and the subsequent rise in the human population. Apparently there are biofeedback mechanisms that can return the atmospheric carbon dioxide level to the 180 to 280 ppm range if it is elevated by, for example, large volcanic eruptions, but they operate over long time scales. It may be that we humans haven’t burnt such a large proportion of the total carbon sequestered as fossil fuels that those mechanisms will be ineffective, over millennia, at returning the Earth’s atmospheric carbon dioxide levels to the “un-modified” level. I will edit this comment when I have time. Thank you.

text: Not far from where I live, there was a written account of the early settlers felling the trees and burning much of the wood (some would be used for buildings etc). The thing that I found startling is that these above ground fires ignited the organic biomass beneath the surface and the newly created fields would smoke through the winter melting the snow. The amount of organic material in the soils was remarkable when you compare the thin organic layers (top soil) we see today. I am reforesting a gravel pit... no easy task with course mineral soils.

Trees also tap into deep ground water, depleting and evaporating it, to cause clouds and local weather, creating a cloudier, damper climate than otherwise. On a very small, crowded island such as Britain, however the Sea will normally bring in sufficient rainfall to undo the need for any additional, rain-producing, effete, local bio-systems, such as a petting forest.

text:
According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years.  That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago.  World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle.  The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de Géophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15°C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. Pépin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

Revised February 2003

text:
Thirty years ago, in my third year of college, I was in a car with my mom. I'd flown back to my parents' house for a holiday, and we were driving down a stretch of freeway that went on flat to the horizon. At the time, I'd just read that to offset a typical 1989 car's emissions, you'd need to plant 40 acres of trees. Looking out the window that day, I can still feel the visceral falling sensation of realizing: there's not enough. Cover every inch of land with trees and it still wouldn't be enough to compensate for all the driving. 



So now the Economist picks this up and has an expert say the same thing 30 years later. I'm sure the great market will solve this....

text:
Notice that they did not talk to anyone involved with planting conifer monocultures. 
I live in Canada and we have lots of Red pine plantations here. Probbably 2-3 Irelands worth of Red pines in my province alone. Those plantations are ugly for sure. They are also a much much faster way to get back to natural forests when they are selectively managed and the shade tolerant old growth species can come up in the shade of the red pines. So letting nature develop in the shade of a properly managed monoculture forest is good for the economy, carbon sequestration and to get back to old growth as fast as possible.

We do not have fertilizers on the pines here. I think they ought to just stop adding fertilizers to those plantations in Ireland

text:
The subject is the issue of monoculture planting.. but it seems to me that is not the real problem either. The problem is that products we make from trees soon rot and go back into the atmosphere. Surely there is a not-too difficult process by which we can put this waste back on the route to becoming coal again. After all this has happened all by itself. It doesn't matter if that process takes a million years, the point is the material stayed on the ground all that time with no management necessary.
Why can't we process all our biodegradable waste this way? This includes sewage and agricultural waste as well. IMO We don't want it to biodegrade. Build coal mountain ranges in the desert or similar. Create new carbon rich soil to cover that desert perhaps.

text:
20,000 years ago ALL of Canada and large swathes of United States, ALL of Scandinavia and large swathes of Russia and Northern Europe (including UK) were mostly devoid of life especially trees. After the glacial maximum 20,000 years ago the world started to rapidly warm and the great ice sheets retreated while the flora and fauna colonized all the lands that had been either, under the ice, or too cold and dry to support life. A vast greening took place which would have 'locked up' vast quantities of CO2 and yet the planet warmed. Equally the last time we were this warm was 120,000 years ago during the Eamian Interglacial. When the Eamian ended and the world grew colder and colder vast areas would have lost all Flora and Fauna thus releasing CO2 back into the atmosphere while the global avarage temp. dropped and stayed there until 20,000 years ago.  
Clearing trees while the earth is warm and in an interglacial will warm the surface and not because of the release of CO2 but because the sun can heat the surface directly and as soon as the surface is cleared. In addition losing tree cover will speed up water evaporation warming the surface further. Here is an account from 1865 which is about slavery but also describes the affect of clear felling forest in Brazil 
"At six o'clock in the morning the overseer forces the poor slave, still exhausted from the evening's labors, to rise from his rude bed and proceed to his work. The first assignment of the season is the chopping down of the forests for the next year's planting, using a scythe to hack down the smaller trees. This work normally goes on for two months, depending upon the type of jungle being cut and the stamina of the slaves.
The next step is the destruction of the large trees, and this, like the previous work, continues for twelve hours each day. At night the slaves return home, where evening work of two or more hours awaits them, depending upon the character of the master. They set fire to the devastated jungle, and then they cut and stack the branches and smaller tree trunks which have escaped the fire and which, occupying the surface of the earth, could hinder development of the crop.
These mounds of branches are again burned, and the result is a sad and devastating scene! Centuries-old tree trunks which two months before had produced a cool, crisp atmosphere over a broad stretch of land, lie on the surface of a field ravaged by fire and covered with ashes, where the slaves are compelled to spend twelve hours under the hot sun of the equator, without a single tree to give them shelter.
This destruction of the forests has exhausted the soil, which in many places now produces nothing but grasses suitable for grazing cattle. The temperature has intensified, and the seasons have become irregular. The rains at times damage the crops, and at other times there is not rain at all. The streams and certain shallow rivers, such as the Itapucuru, have dried up or have become almost unnavigable, and lumber for building has become very rare, or is only found at a great distance from the settlements."

text: @John Peric  In fact 20% of the area (base date 1970) has already been lost.Deforestation and loss of biodiversity have led to high risks of irreversible changes to the Amazon's tropical forests. It has been suggested by modeling studies that the deforestation may be approaching a "tipping point", after which large-scale "savannization" or desertification of the Amazon will take place, with catastrophic consequences for the world's climate, due to a self-perpetuating collapse of the region's biodiversity and ecosystems.[44] Research suggests this tipping point will be reached at about 20-25% deforestation (hence 3% to 8% more than the 17% deforestation already reached in 2018).[45] Since the 17% deforestation has been reached in a period of just 50 years, it is clear that we are very near to this "point of no return".[46]. You can find this information on Wikipedia.

text:
This is a video about monocultures. It was well presented but there is more than a hint that no one is doing enough. The average forest cover for Europen countries is 32% and growing fast. The UK and Ireland are way behind with around 11%. 



Monocultures in temperate climates can be avoided but when dealing with harsher climates then the choice of tree is limited.  An oak will move at least 50 gallons of water a day minimum according to climate.  Conifers, a fraction of that.  In a mature forest, the transpired water remains in the area and recycled by the tree.  In a hot climate, it is lost.  Even if you could supply the water, you have a balancing act between providing enough water for growth and too much which causes the roots to rot. 



The good news is that most Western countries have more trees than 100 years ago.  China seems to be trumping everyone.

text: Trees have a low albedo, meaning they absorb more light. In temperate regions, this cancels out the gains of taking CO2 out of the air. Therefore, according to every scientific paper I ever read on the topic, planting trees in temperate regions has limited effect (approx. zero) on climate change. We need to protect forests in tropical regions, stop with fossil fuels and reduce animal agriculture. Tree planting in places like Northern Europe is not a bad idea but won't help much if at all with climate change.

text:
This video isn't telling the full story. Tree monoculture is the problem, not tree diversity. Also, no one is really saying that planting trees is an excuse to NOT cut fossil fuel emissions; most of us know by now that this will have to be done in addition to planting tons of trees. As for leaving forests to their own devices, I'm all for it, but also wonder about the impacts of invasive species moving in instead. I mean, humans have screwed over the planet so much that natural ecosystems aren't really that natural anymore. 

Long story short, protect trees, stop acting like money is the most important thing in the world (because that attitude is killing us), plant trees native to their areas, and go for a walk in the woods (without your nose in your phone) so you can get a better appreciation for what it is we need to protect.

Hello, my names James, I’m writing this on behalf of ‘Restore Sustain Thrive: Brazil Reforestation & Permaculture'. Restore Sustain Thrive is social-environmental development project here in Brazil. The main focus of the project is reforestation and the promotion of permaculture in the Atlantic forest (Mata Atlântica) region to the north of Rio de Janeiro. To get things started we are conducting a crowd funding campaign. We would greatly appreciate any assistance you can give and if you could distribute this to friends, family and to any individuals or organisations that you think may be able to assist. author: James Ribeiro Duthie

text:
This "film" looks at a topic from one side and cherry picks. They take short rotation eucalyptus numbers to use as an example for carbon binding in mono-culture forest? Even you must have thought that to be a bit misleading. An average Norway spruce "mono-culture" rotation in Europe is something like 60 years. 

*Most planted forest store more carbon and faster then natural regenerated ones (specially in the northern hemisphere), simply because the species used grow faster and the coverage is higher. 
*Ireland was not the European country with the lowest forest cover at that time, that was Iceland.
*Its true that short rotation stands (10-25 years) do release the carbon back into the air rather fast, some into paper, but often as fuel (Scandinavia has excelled at this) This fuel is then carbon neutral and new carbon is not added to the atmosphere with fossil fuel. Additionally, you have many short rotation stands. So on the average, even if you harvest one, there is always a huge amount of carbon being stored in others stands. You could of course just use the land for cattle grazing, would that be better?
*You have three pillars of sustainability. Ecological, economical and social. Production forests are needed, whether sign holding folk like them or not. Ironically the signs they are holding were made from production forests, most often mono/duo-cultures. If Ireland does not want to produce their own timber products, it has to come from somewhere.
Of course we need to cut fossil fuel emissions, but we don´t need people attacking one of our solutions just because its not perfect from every angle.
*If landowners would be paid for their carbon sequestration, that would be an economic incentive, but like i mentioned, planted forests would still bind more so they would be the best option.

There are multiple other things to address but I´ll stop there. But we need more trees on this planet.

text: Have You walked into the the Forest on a hot Summer day? The coolness of the air envelopes you.... it is actually potentially a life saver in the heat waves we are having nowadays. Even when you drive through a little clump of trees by the road on a hot day - right away you feel a cool breeze through the open windows..... the trouble is most people don't know this - they hide in their air conditioned buildings and drive around with their windows shut and AC running on full... Having a lot of Forested areas in the neighborhood prevents drying out of agricultural soil. The trees breathe out a lot of moisture in the evening which covers the thirsty land with a layer of refreshing moisture through the night....  Forested areas prevent big winds - because they prevent the big temperature differences between scorched "naked" land and cold air in the upper atmosphere...  We have to understand the TREES were here on this Planet for a reason - they are a very if not Most important part of climate regulation, not for beauty, or entertainment or for our profits.

text:
I wouldn't call this trouble with trees... more like trouble with humans. Who knew that the big announcements to plant forests of trees was actually an announcement to gain carbon credits and later sell the trees for timber?


The charity, Green Ethiopia, has the right idea; leave the land alone if it'll regenerate naturally, otherwise incentivize locals to help replant and become stewards of the land.


If you live in a suburban house with a yard, you can help, too. Stop mowing your lawn, stop caring about manicured grass, and watch nature take over. Within just a few years, you'll see native trees start to take over your yard. I've been doing it for a couple years on my side yard (in Southern Ontario, Canada), and I now have a mini forest of trees; black walnut, bitternut, American elm, Tree of Heaven, red mulberry, and a whole host of other types of plants that are not trees. Given, some communities have by-laws which require homeowners to "mow the lawn", but if you are able to let it grow wild, it's a great idea.

text: The answer is endemic forests, you let them grow big, then you clear cut in long thin strips across the landscape. Leave all the debris (no slash piles) and don’t replant (you want the forest to grow back as a selected response to the conditions - not be guessing at what you should plant). By cutting a mature forest, the litter goes back into the soil because there is rich topsoil that hosts life that eats it before it oxidizes. By cutting in long thin strips, erosion is mitigated and regrowth and decomposition of debris is rapid. By clear cutting, you make harvesting much more efficient (efficiency is energy).

text: @Theodor Joensen  Well firstly, the keeling curve is a graph. So I don't know why you even asked that question. Secondly the keeling curve shows that since the 1960s the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere has increased by around 20-25%. From 320 parts per million by volume to over 400ppmv. And finally, what you are referencing about CO2 lag time is historically shown to occur at the end of ice ages. Where a temperature increase melts ice, which releases trapped carbon, which accellerates the rise in temperature, which melts more ice, releases more carbon in a feedback loop which ends the ice age. This is a process that occurs naturally and slowly over centuries....not rapidly over 40 years like we're seeing now.

text:
This is the Disney version of environmentalism very much in line with Agenda 21 (the depopulation of the countryside and cramming the population into consumer tax milking farms or cities as most people know them). Permaculture is one possible way forward, I studied forestry and forest economics at uni and worked as a forest manager for a few years and became quite disillusioned with the unnatural and ecologically unsustainable mainstream approach to tree farming. It is the bean counters and narrow minded science based on economic return and tax incentives for the land owners that determine what species are economically viable and rarely take into consideration the eco services they provide, hence the vast swathes of monoculture plantations. Permaculture (permanent agriculture because we need to feed ourselves also) and forest gardens not only stabilise the soil and slow water run off, reduce albedo  and actually help with the hydrodynamics of the ecosystem but provides a wide variety of produce during all stages of growth by mimicking the natural layers of the ecosystem  with economically important canopy species that may provide an interim harvest of nuts for many years (nut oils, nut flour and the nuts) as well as a final timber crop, a sub canopy layer of say for example fruit trees, a shrub layer of soft fruits and berries, a herbaceous layer, a ground layer and a root layer can all be incorporated to grow interim and long term crops and finally a vine layer such as runner beans, grapes etc. All of which can be managed and harvested prior to canopy closure. Support species are also used, especially on seriously degraded land that have been poisoned and grazed to the point of desertification or degradation. This is a very brief description of permaculture, it is less mechanised and quite labour intensive so would require a vast number of ‘stewards’ to work and harvest the produce year round (massive employment opportunity for the right people) with huge diversity of produce so you haven’t got all your eggs in one basket, cell grazing can also be incorporated to maintain a lush ground flora. You can let your imagination run wild. The whole carbon issue is a red herring though. The famous ‘hockey stick’ graph which Michael Mann et. Al., gave us and is the foundation for all the carbon hysteria, (goodness knows how many times it was cited by the alleged 97% of climate scientists who back the CO2/global warming story) and the IPCC’s tax grab has never been independently verified or reproduced to the point that he spent (or rather his backers spent) millions of dollars on a defamation suit against a Dr. Tim Ball who basically called him a fraud. The case went on for eight years and was finally dismissed and Tim Ball was awarded court costs when Mann refused to allow his publicly funded research from Pennsylvania State University, including data, statistical method and computer models to be presented in court to prove his case for defamation. He even managed to loose the Medieval Warming Period with his statistical shenanigans! I’m not saying that climate change does not exist however. A weakening magnetosphere leading to increased cosmic ray penetration (increased cloud nucleation leading to cooling not warming, and an uptick in seismic activity) is leading to a destabilisation of the jet stream influencing the extreme weather conditions the planet is now experiencing. This is all cyclic, has happened before and will happen again and is largely influenced by solar activity. Yes we do need to address pollution and the way we treat this planet. We need to learn to interact with and understand our environment and ecosystems and let them work for us and not rape it for the out of control consumerism and profit motives of the corporatocracy.  
People also argue the point with tree ring data which is not a reliable method of studying historical climate where a hot dry summer and a cold wet growing season can yield a similar result as well as varying from species to species, tree spacing etc., (I did study a bit of dendrochronology also). Ever wondered why ‘skeptics’ are shouted down constantly and sensible debate avoided at all cost?

Sanskrit subhashitam on the planting, conserving, preservation, protection, promotion of trees and importance of trees for water bodies, maintenance , protection, preservation and sustance of these water bodies, the importance of maintaining equilibrium on green house gas emissions by releasing oxygen in the atmosphere and absorbing carbon di oxide from the atmosphere (i.e. the scientific jargon - carbon sequesteration - the scientific term) is appended::



दश गृह समो कूपो दसकूपसमो वापी दशवापीसमो ह्रदः।

दशह्रदसमः पुत्रो दशपुत्र समो द्रुमः ॥  

- मत्स्य पुराण


Transliteration:

dashakUpasamaa vaapI dashavaapIsamo hradaH|

dashahradasamaH putro dashaputra samo drumaH||

- matsya puraaNa


Meaning of the subhAShita:

A pond is equal to ten wells.  A dansk of water (reservoir) is worth ten (such) ponds.  (Then again,) ten (such) reservoirs are same as a son (offspring).  (But), a tree is equal to ten (such) sons.


Commentary:

Water is an integral part of life's very existence.  Infact, we have known man to send out space ships to different spacial objects, just to detect the existence of water.  When such is the case, a well obviously is an invaluable asset to living beings. A well after all, is a small body of water. It fulfills the water needs of 10 households in a cluster.  Without a doubt, a pond can easily be equated to ten such wells. 


The water in ten ponds can be easily contained in a reservoir.  But then, a son (good, cultured, educated one specially), is no match to even ten such reservoirs!   Because, a child quenches the thirst of the parents, in a similar way!! But then, there is something that can even equal ten such sons!!  That is none other than a 'tree'.


Why is that?  How can 1 tree equal 10 sons or 100 reservoirs or 1000 ponds or 10,000 wells?!!!  Well... :), here's the deal. One tree in it's life time, holds in clouds that can equal all of the above bodies of water.  How about a son. How can a tree be better than him? It sure is, because, a person who plants it today will never know how many people shall benefit from that tree.  In reality, the true meaning of life is said to be - to plant trees, under whose shade one does not expect to sit! The many fruit the tree bears, shall satiate the hunger of birds/animal/people.  Many a rain clouds it might bring to the neighborhood and quench the thirst of the needy. When he plants the sapling, he is actually doing service to many beings without realizing. Moreover, the tree may live there for generations beyond the planter and his son and still keep serving the people, giving them water, shade and fruit. 


Hence a tree is equated to so many things.  Then what does felling a tree mean? It means we are, with our own bare hands, although theoretically, slaying so many sons and drying up so many water sources! 


It is said that trees are the best antiques and the groves were God's first temples.  Strive and save those antique temples now and always!

text:
Title is total clickbait. It’s not the trouble with trees. It’s the trouble with tree monoculture. Anyone who has ever done extensive tree planting with a forest management program (such as myself) knows you are better off selecting a minimum of 12 species, and ideally double that... to avoid monoculture infestations that decimate your plantation. Additionally, the variety must include mostly local species so they thrive naturally, and fruit species for the local animals to thrive also. As for “harvesting every ten years lowering carbon sequestration”, that is also a crock if done correctly. You first cull weaker trees at 7 and 14 years, allowing stronger trees to expand and cover the areas previously occupied by weaker trees: thereby fortifying your forest. And as for a self- sustaining business concern, you pick trees to cut after 20 or 30 yrs and you don’t cut more than 1 or 2 percent of the trees you planted and replant new trees in their place right away... so your average tree will reach 50 to 100 yrs, you’ll never have land clearings, and your carbon sequestration will be minimally affected by the ongoing commercial concern. 

Simple as that. TREES ARE THE SOLUTION! Monocultures are not.

I believe education is the beginning (and there are many factors to address in that respect in poor and HOT countries). As far as I’ve witnessed, no matter how well intentioned government incentives are, their bureaucracy and potential for corrupt favoritism cannot compete with a free market economy. “Give a man a fish and he will eat for a day. Teach a man how to fish and you feed him for a lifetime.”

text:
My dad has about 30 acres of mixed deciduous bush in southern Ontario and he's owned it for 65 years.   Every 15 years, or so,  he marks certain trees and a tree harvesting company comes in and cuts them down and my dad makes a tidy sum off it.   The thing is,  unless you know that bush really well,   you'd believe that this bush has never changed a bit.   


The trees grow wild.   There is no planting regime and it's not necessary as only certain size trees are cut.   When the harvesters are done,   a person walking through that bush the following year wouldn't even know that any cutting had been done.   This bush should last many more lifetimes if managed this way.   You don't have to clear cut to make money and you don't have to waste time and money with tree planting projects if you do it correctly.

text: Aleido Vellerophon Yes, that’s exactly right. A mono-culture, or many trees of one species, is very susceptible to pests. While planting many different species, especially native species, will result in a more natural forest-like environment that will help resist pests and contagious diseases. Also, planting not just lumber yielding trees, but also inserting variety such as fruit bearing trees, flower bearing trees, fire resisting trees, etc. will help establish a healthy animal environment also... which in turn is beneficial to the forest (bees - pollination, animals - natural fertilizers, etc.).  Diversity in nature, just like in humans, helps complement strengths and minimize weaknesses.

text: juscurious I completely agree and understand your concern. And believe me, I believe in the smallest government possible and the least subsidies possible. I’m a true believer of free enterprise but with sustainability. The ideal model I was referring to was cutting and producing furniture, wooden structures, wooden devices... I have never been involved in a timber company in order to determine what percentage they can live with processing. It may be 2%, 5%? It all depends on the size of their plantations, the size of their business, and the years their trees need to grow. Whichever is that number for each individual timber company, if they are going to have a sustainable business, they need to find the right balance for their forest vs demand. To put it another way, you cannot take all the fish out of the ocean if you want to have a sustainable fishing company... otherwise you’d be fishing yourself out of a job. Likewise, you cannot cut such a large percentage of trees annually as to not allow your company to have enough trees in the future. So a balance with nature is also a balance for your company.

author: Richard Monroe

text: I have a weird view of trees and carbon sequestration. When a tree dies naturally the fungi and bacteria break it back down into CO2. The only way to prevent this recycling is to store the dead trees in an environment that doesn't allow this process to occur. Throughout geological history this was done under ground, hence the oil fields. If we're serious about carbon sequestration using plants, we have to cull and bury them, or turn them into something indigestible, and plant new trees to continue the process. Letting the forest stand indefinitely limits the amount of CO2 you can pull from the air, because existing trees can only get so big and once they are big they block new trees from receiving sunlight. In the end when these big trees die the carbon is recycled back into the air by microorganisms. Cutting and burying the trees extends the amount of time the carbon is sequestered and makes space for new tree growth. By looking at the age-growth curve of whatever species you plant you can determine the best time to chop and bury them. The downside is you will also end up burying the nutrients stored within the tree along with the carbon. That's my thoughts on sequestration. When it comes to natural forests I would want to keep them as untouched as possible.

text:
​ @pablo rages   Yes, it was much higher 500 million years ago, when the earth was largely uninhabited by complex life forms, but it has not been this high for 14 million years.  I'm not sure why you can't understand the simple concept of the relationship between CO2 concentration and global temps. They go hand in hand, and the world was a lot hotter 14 million years ago and at all times the CO2 concentrations were high. And it is irrelevant to mention the what happened 500 million years ago because for 10,000 years before the industrial revolution CO2 levels stayed at around 280 ppm. Since the industrial revolution when fossil fuel started being burned it has increased to 415 ppm. Only 30 years ago it was at 350. Do you understand the difference between CO2 levels rising by 33% in only the last 100 years and not rising at all over the previous 10,000 years, and rising so quickly during a period that coincides with the beginning of the large scale burning of carbon and production of carbon dioxide by humans?  Try to educate yourself on the correct information instead of learning from fox news or right wing denier websites. Trust scientists who know way more than you do about the climate, and stop trying to use your own ignorance to understand this problem.

text:
The underlying issue is our farming model.  And fortunately, just like the internet is bridging the gap between the consumer and custom producers, autonomous robots will soon restore the feasibility of micro-agriculture, where animals, crops, vegetables and fruit trees grow in the same small-scale intensive farm, where trees are part of the system.
Also this video misses the main problem of tropical deforestation, which is the loss of biodiversity.  Biodiversity is the material result of evolution, the most powerful parallel computer ever built.  By throwing away the organisms and molecules of the destroyed rain forest we lose yottaflops of past computation--something we are still centuries away from re-creating, even with Moore's law holding.

text: @Mr Brightside  that's not what the videos are about. Cattle and grass together have profound emergent properties that we are only now just beginning to understand. You can't understand complex systems solely by their parts.
author: Douglas Oak

text:
@Mr Brightside  it seems to me you can't understand the material.

Let me make it simple: 

Grass has roots. 

The size of those roots is balanced by the size of the blade. 

This is due to hydrolic pressure. 

Cows eats grass. 

Hydrolic pressure changes. 

Grass terminates root branches to maintain pressure balance. 

Those abandoned roots get stuck in the ground in long stable carbon chains; sucking down carbon and building new soil. (Which also absorbes CO2) 

Grass grows new stem and new roots. 

This all happens at 10 times the speed of trees because osmosis is more effective over small areas than large ones.

I'm sorry if this truth endangers your tree planting buisness but the "truth" your promoting is endangering all of our lives because instead of trees we could be planting grass.

author: Jh5578

text:
jhunt5578 
These are great points and well referenced. If we cut our meat and dairy consumption by half and ate more plant based food instead, the pressure to deforest would be gone, and we would free up 10s if millions of sq km of land to reforest and return to natural wetlands and peat.
I sometimes think the issue of land use is seen as a nice to have. On the contrary - it we got this right, we could secure much better food supplies, completely change the outlook for warming and restore massive amounts of lost life and biodiversity all at the same time. 
It's potentially transformative AND unlike the energy system, we can actually have a big impact with consumer choices. 
But government action will still be required to change things fast enough. Meat and dairy must pay for the damage they do, and only regulation can internalise those costs.
author: Michael RCH

text:
@Michael RCH  I agree that regulation is needed, the cost of animal products is artificially low due to subsidies. Animal ag's damage goes further, it's the leading cause of rainforest deforestation, ocean dead zones, species extinction, top soil erosion, it causes up to half of all ocean acidification and up to 46% of ocean plastics from miles and miles of fishing line and nets lost by vessels. At our current rate of fishing we'll see fish stock collapse by 2050. Animal ag also uses half of the worlds grain and 1/3rd of our fresh water and we're headed towards a water crisis by 2040. 

On top of that there are health benefits to ditching meat and dairy. 

Harvard Law review: “Climate change. Ocean dead zones. Fisheries depletion. Species extinction. Deforestation. World hunger. Food safety. Heart disease. Obesity. Diabetes. The list goes on. There is one issue at the heart of all these global problems that is too often overlooked by private individuals and policy makers alike—our demand for and reliance on animal products.” http://harvardelr.com/2015/10/26/elrs-a-leading-cause-of-everything-one-industry-that-is-destroying-our-planet-and-our-ability-to-thrive-on-it/

Don't forget that market consumerism has a great effect too. We don't have to wait for the government to tell us to eat sustainably, we can change our diets now. In this talk from Oxford researcher Joseph Poore he notes that the annual GHG mitigated between a meat eater and a Vegan is a co2 equivalent to 11 return flights from London to Rome. https://youtu.be/8miQs3mPGu8

Eating animal products is like fly tipping or emptying plastics into the ocean or dumping oil into soil - it's incredibly harmful to the environment but most do not understand how severe a plate of food can be.
author: Jh5578

text:
jhunt5578 
Amen to all that. I have bookmarked those pages.
My familiar went veggie and mostly vegan about a year ago. 
The great but tragic thing is just how easy it is!
And yet many people, even those with the right intentions, just instinctively resist.
I think part of it is the historical reputation of vegetationism and especially veganism.
But that is changing a bit. I think not eating meat is becoming a much more acceptable thing culturally- not the object of a raised eyebrow and suspicion of holier-than-though fussiness.
That social change can't come fast enough.
We really need to have animal agriculture directly connected to environmental catastrophe and abuse in people's minds. 
Eating is so visceral. Once you take against meat products, it's actually hard to go back!

text:
According to NASA the greening of the planet over the last two decades represents an increase in leaf area on plants and trees equivalent to the area covered by all the Amazon rainforests. There are now more than two million square miles of extra green leaf area per year, compared to the early 2000s – a 5% increase. It's also noteworthy  that average global temperature has dropped by almost half a degree Celsius since the Super El-Niño three years ago. And although global temperatures have been rising slowly for thirty years, the warming trend has noticeably been slowing rather than accelerating since the start of this century — in complete contrast to the predictions of almost all climate models. Only one-third to two-thirds of the predicted global warming has taken place in the last thirty years, even though more than half of all industrial carbon dioxide emissions since the beginning of the industrial revolution have been released during that time. Contrary to all predictions, neither the number nor the intensity of drought, floods, forest fires or hurricanes has increased in the last thirty years. Even sea level rise is much more gradual and constant than predicted. According to NASA, the average sea level rise since 1993 is 3.2 millimetres per year. 


But never mind, move along, there is nothing to see here. BTW the sky is still falling due to a climate emergency.

text:
Everyone has been fooled and both the American and British media have openly been told not to interview anyone who disputes that it is humans that have caused the climate to change. If the oil and gas had not been used, where would all the plastics have come from (which sadly, humans dump in land fill sites, rivers and the sea!)? Where have many of the oil based chemicals, tar, medicines, food additives etc. etc. come from? (See a partial list of 6,000 products made from oil at https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/partial-list-over-6000-products-made-from-one-barrel-oil-steve-pryor). ; How would we have produced the energy we have used? How would we have transported food and goods around the planet...by horse and cart and rowing boats? How would we have heated and cooled our homes? Well, we could have cut down ALL of the trees I suppose...It is bad enough that we have cut down most of the trees in most countries and in particular around the tropics where the tree cover historically controlled the world climate! Those living in or near or visiting rainforest will be aware how tropical rains are absorbed by the trees very quickly after a storm, since each tree can absorb its own weight in water. Evaporation in the rainforest helps to keep the temperature down, particularly in the tropics, whereas cleared land retains the radiant heat of the sun. Then look at the main real current proximate cause of climate change... THE POLE SHIFT! 


The concept of 'global warming'. and 'global temperature increases', of a variety of alleged current and future ranges, is not of any scientific value. Global temperatures vary from year to year and from geographical location to location. Many of the temperature and climate recording stations were installed many years ago in relatively rural locations where over time, housing, industrial and road developments have increased localized temperatures and altered localized climate. The increased extreme weather now becoming common worldwide has also produced record high and low temperatures worldwide,  year on year. Last year (2018) a record low temperature of -83 C was recorded in Siberia and a record high temperature of 51.3 C was recorded in Algeria. With huge variations worldwide over short and long periods of time, proposing an average global temperature is completely illogical, unscientific and fictional. Temperature recording stations are not spread at equidistant locations in similar environments over every square mile of the Earth's surface which would be an absolute requirement if the data had any value at all. In addition, the use of historic data from air bubbles in ice containing CO2, has now been under scrutiny following the realisation that gases locked up in ice are absorbed at different rates in the ice and the remaining air and its constituents does not necessarily represent the air trapped at historic moments in time.


Temperatures on the planet swung from -83oC to + 56oC last year. Seasonal and day/night time temperatures can swing 60oC on many land surfaces, so talking about an average temperature increase of 2o C as being catastrophic would make very little difference to many areas of the Earth. Far more serious is the surge in extreme climate change with the escalation of droughts, floods, unseasonal climatic changes, earthquakes and volcanic eruptions. These increasing extreme climate variations are also dramatically affecting the current world food output. See https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ELA_VdMN6eY and https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZCtZ6SJlH7U ; and many others. The current escalation of these changes cannot under any circumstances be caused by the tiny increase in CO2. 


Whilst cyclical historic climatic patterns are a guide to future climate, so many factors and accurate data are missing from historic data and projected computer models. Our planet and its climate change is affected by its variable orbit around the sun, solar activity cycles, variations in earthquake and volcanic activity, pole shift, solar and cosmic radiation, impact from passing planetary debris, to name but a few of the causes. Seasonal cyclical climatic variations throughout the calendar year depend on location, the Sun's position during the day and night and the elliptical orbit and distance between the Earth and the Sun. The increase in the release of CO2 by man, has a minute affect on weather. The release of methane from livestock whose population numbers are similar to the human population are far more damaging than the CO2 man produces. In addition, we are led to believe the alleged heat trapped by the 1 in 2,500 molecules of CO2 in the atmosphere makes a bee line for the CO2 molecules and does not go anywhere near the 2,499 molecules of other atmospheric gases! Radiant heat from the Earth's surface does bounce around CO2 molecules, but ultimately it escapes. Comparing CO2 to the affect glass in a greenhouse has on retaining heat is ridiculous and unscientific! There is no glass window in the atmosphere or glass dome around the planet! What makes the concept that CO2 is a 'greenhouse gas' even more ridiculous is that CO2 is a main input for photosynthesis and not only are concentration levels of CO2 in greenhouses much lower, many owners of greenhouses have to inject more CO2 to increase plant growth! The reason greenhouses are warmer than the surrounding environment is because the glass prevents the escape of the trapped heat which is also a requirement for rapid plant growth. People in glass hoses should not blame the CO2! The Clouds have an infinitely greater ability to trap heat since cloud as we are all very aware, clouds help prevent frosts and prevents the sun from warming the Earth's surface! As many who fly will testify, the tops of clouds are white and not only prevent heat from the sun reaching the Earth's surface, but reflect heat back away from the Earth's surface.


Of greater affect on the world climate is the destruction of forest, particularly around the tropics where lack of trees to absorb the sun's radiation causes tropical (not global) warming and the absorption of much more moisture from the tropical seas as a result of higher air and sea temperature. Global solar minimum records may have been a guide to  future climate from past records, however, the affects of the pole shift are altering global conditions and projections from historic records and cycles. At the last GSM, we were not experiencing the extreme temperatures and extreme weather events now being recorded! Also, we did not experience such a huge increase in earthquake and volcanic activity. (Sometimes as many as 4000 earthquakes over 2.5 on the Richter scale each month instead of 200, 16 years ago and over 70 erupting volcanoes each month as opposed to 3, 16 years ago.) Huge cracks and sink holes have also increased year by year in the last 16 years as a result of the stress on the crust from the current crustal slip.


So one cause for the escalation of extreme weather events is simple...less trees in the tropics each year....less to absorb the suns radiation = tropical warming (NOT GLOBAL WARMING!). Higher temperature around the tropics = more moisture evaporated from the oceans producing much warmer, denser and increased cloud production (hence more flooding in tropics where tree cover is reduced).....then more and denser ‘tropical rainforest clouds’ carrying more moisture, escape the tropics as intense heat on cleared land creates lift to allow these clouds to escape the tropics on trade winds...hence regional cooling effect away from the tropics as cloud cover increases and increased rain and snow fall away from the tropics, whilst extra cloud cover also traps the extra heat travelling up from the tropics. Less trees in the tropics each year = less biomass to sequester the CO2.  As the ocean warms, the warmer seas travel north to the Arctic and south to the Antarctic. As warmer air from the tropics travels north and south, air is warmer in the Arctic and in the Antarctic....simples!’ The warmer air and seas distorts the position of the jet stream pushing it north towards west Canada and north towards the UK but there is a counteractive force pushing the jet stream south at some geographical locations as a result of the increase in cloud cover escaping the Tropics, which cools some areas of the ocean through reduced radiation from the sun.

text:
What an impressive dump of disinformation, well done. 

<<How would we have produced the energy we have used? How would we have transported food and goods around the planet...by horse and cart and rowing boats>>

The fact that oil and plastics have been good for humanity doesn't mean that climate change also must be good. It's not black or white. Things are not 100% good or 100% bad, grow up. 

<<Then look at the main real current proximate cause of climate change... THE POLE SHIFT!>>

Geological records of previous magnetic pole reversals (actual reversals, not the wobbling that has been witnessed) have not found that they cause any significant effect on climate. 
https://www.nasa.gov/topics/earth/features/2012-poleReversal.html

<<With huge variations worldwide over short and long periods of time, proposing an average global temperature is completely illogical, unscientific and fictional.>> 

This variation is precisely why the change is measured in anomalies, not absolute temperatures. With an anomaly the day to day and location to location variation is eliminated, all that matters is the change over time, which is much more subtle and for which the trend is easy to see (it is going up.) 

<<The current escalation of these changes cannot under any circumstances be caused by the tiny increase in CO2.>> 

Why not? Why should we believe you, and not the majority of climatologists and, for that matter, probably 99% of so-called "skeptics" who also do not subscribe to your pole shift theory? 

<<Comparing CO2 to the affect glass in a greenhouse has on retaining heat is ridiculous and unscientific! There is no glass window in the atmosphere or glass dome around the planet!>>

Do you really think this is how scientists think it works? "Greenhouse" is just a word, it has nothing to do with how it actually works. CO2 as a molecule creates a dipole moment when IR of certain wavelengths interacts with it. This has been known since the 19th century. 

<<many owners of greenhouses have to inject more CO2 to increase plant growth!>>

Completely irrelevant to its ability to absorb infrared radiation and be a greenhouse gas. 

<<..less trees in the tropics each year....less to absorb the suns radiation = tropical warming (NOT GLOBAL WARMING!)>>

Forests tend to be darker than the grasland that replaces them, so your local insolation effect is backwards. The CO2 effect is what is global.

author: David

text: David ok thanks but still what is so alarming? It seems the only thing consistent is change. It was unbelievably hot in the 1930s when “man made” CO2 was much lower. Then in the 1970s, when pollution was not as regulated as today and LA’s smog was so thick you could cut it with a knife, scientist were claiming we were headed for another ice age. 2018-2019 winter in Colorado had epic snow fall most of the season. Records were set across the board. Yet just the season before there was significantly less snow events which also broke records. If we can’t predict what the weather is going to do more than 3 or 4 days out how can we predict what will happen in 11 years? Again, where’s the crisis?
author: Oden

text:
@Oden  The hot temperatures in the 1930s were just in the USA, i.e. < 2% of the planet's surface area. Globally the 1930s were not even close to today. 

Some scientists warned of an ice age in the 70s -- assuming air pollution would not be controlled and keep getting worse and that this out offset the warming from increased CO2. Air pollution was controlled but CO2 was not. Still, even during this time there were 5-10 times more papers predicting warming than were predicting cooling. 

Snowfall events do not prove anything, unfortunately. Snow still happens even with a +1C world. Temperatures on average are still rising. 

Weather is chaotic and difficult to predict but overall trends are not. Chaoctic variations average out reliably over time. When you have a consistent forcing, like a greenhouse gas increase, you can predict warming on average over time even without knowing in depth what is happening with every cloud or gust of wind on every square foot of the planet. 

As for why it is concerning, it is not so much 2019 that was ever predicted to be that severe. The concerning predictions are for 2050 and 2100. A 5C warming would change the planet as much as the change between today, and the ice age. An ice age is only about 5-6 C cooler and the world is completely different -- sea levels hundreds of feet lower, glaciers miles thick covering much of the continents, weather completely different. 

This is the climate we are adapted to. It is the one we have laid our farmland, built our coastal cities and decided where we should and should not inhabit. A changing climate represents an enormous, unwelcome, unneeded additional challenge on a future already set to have many other challenges. It is an unstoppable game of chase we are forcing ourselves to play, chasing across political boarders (conflict), chasing new lands and abandoning old ones at the cost of trillions. If the worst predictions are realized the result will be catastrophic.
author: David

text: David thanks again for your well thought out explanation. Sounds like you know what your talking about. However I’m still not convinced “our house is on fire”.
author: Oden

text:
@Oden  The problem with the argument of whether or not it's a catastrophe is that this term is relative to different people. It's subjective. Some (a surprisingly high number) of people seem to think that if all life on Earth is not wiped out, then it's nothing at all to worry about. Others would say a single species of tree frog going extinct is a 'catastrophe' to be avoided at all costs. 

Based on what's observed and predicted I think it's pretty clear to most people it's at least a cause for serious concern. Of course a cost vs benefit trade off should be considered to the best of our ability. I would tend to consider doing absolutely nothing to be just as dangerous as knee-jerk, poorly thought out draconian measures that send billions into poverty.
author: David
