text:
@Oden  And this argument is a total red herring in my opinion. You may as well attack dermatologists who warn of the link between UV exposure and skin cancer because, hey, plants need sun too so they shouldn't "demonize" it. It's a baffling, "if it's not 100% bad it must be 100% good" oversimplification to me.  

Every scientist who is concerned about climate change understands that CO2 is vital for photosynthesis. This is not news, nor is it news that plants have been around for billions of years before humans started burning fossil fuels. We are not their saviors. CO2 emissions are directly responsible for rapidly forcing an uncontrollable, dramatic climate shift that has the potential to have many very harmful effects on humanity. The fact that plants need it is not a valid argument to be complacent about this.
author: David

text: David ok I’m sorry I didn’t realize it was an argument. I thought we were discussing adapting to changing climates. But in that case, I didn’t say plants need us I said we need plants. They are our saviors. And now I come back to my original question; how is 0.0004% of the earth’s atmosphere “directly responsible for rapidly forcing an uncontrollable, dramatic climate shift that has the potential to have many very harmful effects on humanity”? It’s so minute there’s no way it can tip the scale to catastrophe. No way.
author: Oden

text:
@Oden  << I’m sorry I didn’t realize it was an argument. I thought we were discussing adapting to changing climates. >> 

Um, I meant "argument" as in "line of reasoning", not "argument" as in "fight" (obviously). 

<<But in that case, I didn’t say plants need us I said we need plants. They are our saviors.>> 

Yes, and so you said we therefore shouldn't demonize the CO2 that these plants depend on. Sure sounds like you're saying they need us, not that your corrected version here is any less of a red herring. 

<<How is 0.0004% of the earth’s atmosphere “directly responsible for rapidly forcing an uncontrollable, dramatic climate shift >>

First of all it's .04%, not .0004%, but never mind. Instead of saying "oh it must not be true" why not try understanding why scientists actually think it's true?

Basically 400 ppm is more than sufficient for photons traveling through the entire height of the troposphere to interact with. It's not a guess or a crazy theory, you can literally see it and measure it. The greenhouse effect is dominated by water vapor, but there are wavelengths over which H2O is transparent to IR and CO2 is not. This is where CO2 makes the difference, and within these ranges (again, where no other gas has any effect) you can already see complete absorption. Just from your .04%

As concentration increases, the absorption efficiency increases as well. This means more solar energy persisting in the the troposphere, every second of every day, including at night.

Now I'm sure you'll come back and say "ok but prove the CATASTROPHE" which is basically the same as asking to summarize decades worth of research and hundreds of thousands of pages which is just not possible.

author: Oden

text: Water vapor has a natural way in which it is removed from the atmosphere. It's called precipitation. The overall global average absolute humidity changes with temperature. Water vapor is a feedback to warming or cooling from other causes, it does not spontaneously change and control temperature changes on a long-term (years and decades) time scale.
author: David

text: And then, when it has precipitated (thanks for explaining what it's called), what does it do then? If it doesn't soak below ground, it will evaporate. It will also flood, extensively, as we have seen here in the UK. A tree is not a one-trick pony, whereas every single technological solution is. This is not a one-dimensional one-gauge-in-the-red, Homer Simpson style emergency. This is a complex issue, probably also exacerbated by 5 million (and rising) microwave emitters running 24/7 in a closed atmosphere, which can only heat the atmosphere, as anything else is scientifically impossible. Again, why are we blaming CO2 and why are certain parties so set against natural solutions? And who wants a low CO2 atmosphere on a treeless planet with a load of humming extractors? Oh, but the numbers will be within range, I forgot. That's alright then.

author: David

text: Thanks David. I think we are being asked to change in greater ways than media like The Economist can understand (or countenance, perhaps). Economic systems that reward the serving of life, not its destruction (war, deforestation, etc.), would shift the whole game very quickly. We have to recognise that all of our most hallowed science was built on excluding the human and the energy of life from the equation. This has brought great understanding in many areas, but now that the technology based on it has become so vast, we are faced with the reality of systems that have nothing whatsoever to do with the thriving and fulfilment of living beings, and no science (in the Western mainstream, which is so dominating the world at the moment) to help us understand why. From there we are trying to re-balance something that is huge, self-regulating, living and incomprehensible, when we don't even have a science that tells us what balance is or how to achieve it. I don't think we'll get far while powerful countries default to aggressively expressed self-interest, but currently, that's where the money is and so the market cheers it on. I'm actually very optimistic, just because we actually have all the solutions we need (most being currently marginalised by existing interests) and because the old narratives are looking really flaky to more people than ever.

author: GEORGELET4

text: @GEORGELET4  I go where the evidence points, which is that human activities are warming the planet. There are multiple independent lines of evidence by thousands of scientists that support this. It can (and does) fill several textbooks. Proxy records (for example the "hockey stick") are not at all necessary to prove this simple fact, although subsequent studies by other scientists have also confirmed the basic shape. And even if there were significant global temperature swings in the past 1,000 years (which there weren't), this would still mean absolutely nothing as to what kinds of temperature increases we can expect to see from a doubling of atmospheric CO2. The physics of radiative heat transfer do not depend on there having been a perfectly stable climate to begin with.

author: Na Mo

text: @Jens Petersen  I live in a subtropical area, and have worked for many years in tropical and equatorial areas. The warmer the climate, the fastest is forest regrowth / regeneration. In subtropical areas, if you do not cut your grass, for example, tree species already start recolonizing, and grow in height at a rate of about 1 meter per year, so in about 5 years you have already a young natural forest established. That is why people use fire, to control this regrowth, that is even faster in tropical and equatorial areas. Of course, tools or machinery could better control the regrowth, but often people are poor and ignorant in these areas, so they use fire. Unfortunately, the result in the long term is land degradation and ultimately desertification.
author: Gabriel Penno Saraiva

text: @Heavy Metal Hair Salon  Most of the planted forests are so for industrial purposes, such as for paper or building materials. So, they are harvested after about 10 years. Then part of the carbon they stored during their lives return to the atmosphere. But during their lifetime they improve the soils, increase moisture and decrease temperatures, and this must be taken into consideration. Some people also complain that most planted species are not indigenous. This is because, like animals, there are only a few domesticated tree species, and these few species are often not indigenous from the region. In Brazil, for example, we plant Eucalyptus a lot, but it is native from Australia. But it is better to have a forest plantation than a pastureland, I can assure you. The more covered the soils are from sunlight, the best for them.
author: Gabriel Penno Saraiva

text: @Tore Lund  Yes, annual farming and pasturelands are very harmful for the environment. There is a trend towards planting trees for substituting annual farming and pastureland. For example, products from trees such as walnuts and almonds can substitute wheat, milk and meat. As they are long term tree crops, they protect the soil from sunlight, allow more water to infiltrate it, provide shelter for animal species and so on. And trees grow much faster in warmer areas, so the impact they have in mitigating climate change is faster too.
author: Gabriel Penno Saraiva

author: GEORGELET4

text: @GEORGELET4  I have seen no convincing evidence that there is a massive "hoax". This is an extraordinary claim and requires extraordinary evidence, and the only "evidence" that's ever presented is laughably childish. The science of man-made global warming makes sense and is directly backed up by multiple independent lines of observational evidence. The case would be equally strong without proxy data from the past (hockey stick), although there have been several studies showing it is basically accurate. The scientific literature is clear that the MWP and LIA were not global events. I believe their magnitude is exaggerated to try to "prove" that any climate change today is natural. This is not "proof" of anything. The fact that climate has changed naturally in the past says absolutely nothing about whether it is changing naturally today. Human activities have transformed the planet and caused CO2 to rise. This has a warming effect as proven by spectroscopy, and the signature of this effect is clear in the warming trend that's observed.
author: David

text: ​ @Joseph Zorzin  Yes. You could say the same thing about terrorism or healthcare, too. Are those things myths too? Anytime there's an opportunity to take advantage of something, people will do it. It doesn't mean the base issue is a myth.
author: David

text: @David  sure, but when groups co-opt such debates- it distorts the debate. I didn't use the word "myth". But I do think there is climate hysteria- and much of that is promoted by the co-opters. Be sure to look at that link. I'm not aware of anyone trying to co-opt terrorism- though healthcare is a mess for countless reasons, in America any way. I happen to like the medical systems in Europe. I'm a lefty! But I don't like this climate hysteria. The latest Time magazine special issue, Sept. 23, is dedicated to the climate issue but in the front, the editor says there shall be NO mention of skeptics- they are verboten. If he gave just  one page mentioning that there are skeptics -  I'd respect that magazine a lot more. I'm neutral so far so I want to see what the skeptics are saying and so far, many make a lot of sense. Climate science is NOT like physics where those scientists can prove their theories. They don't do prophecies for the future. Climate science is a serious effort to find the truth but they're not there yet.
author: Joseph Zorzin

text:
@Joseph Zorzin I also enjoy hearing from skeptics, but actual skeptics, which are unfortunately extremely rare. Most people who call themselves "skeptics" tend to really be little more than gullible conspiracy theorists who don't have a moment of skepticism for the contrarian arguments themselves, and embrace an 'anything-but-carbon, throw whatever you have onto the wall and see what sticks' approach to 'science', which I find rather immature rather than constructive. 

I'm not sure what your point is that other scientists don't make prophecies of the future. First, they do it all the time: geologists, biologists, epidemiologists, computer scientists, ecologists, cosmologists, take your pick. Second, what will happen in the future with respect to the climate is of great interest to many people for many reasons. The changes it could impose are enormous, long-term, and it's much better to prepare in advance for something than to try to fix it after it's already happened. These preparations are big investments and take time, so having the best knowledge we can today is extremely valuable. Who better to take the responsibility for this difficult task than the ones who understand the climate system best? I don't agree with the notion, for example, that scientists should always be completely silent with respect to the potential impact of their findings. If they see the warning signs they should communicate them.
author: David

text: @David  by  skeptics, I mean mostly with scientists such as Patrick Michaels, Judith Curry and many others. Of course they're usually dismissed as idiots or on the take from the Koch brothers. Such fast dismissals only antagonizes those less educated who happen to have doubts about guys like Michael Mann. The reality is that scientists can be wrong- and climate science is extremely complicated- it may be the most complicated of all sciences- with a vast number of variables and many we don't even know about. But  now every newspaper I read and other mainstream media are dominated by climate hysteria. Why do people want to hear from a 15 year old girl from Sweden but not Michaels and Curry and others?  The media have turned it into a circus. The more it becomes a circus- the more people will have doubts.
author: Joseph Zorzin

text:
@Joseph Zorzin  I will not try to defend any tactics of the media other than to say it happens both ways. You can find dozens of prominent, usually right-wing, news outlets that will also, as a policy, never report on any stories that show a negative effect of global warming, or even that it exists at all. And there is certainly no less culpability with regard to using hyperbole for the purpose of hysteria, either. The so-called "skeptics" tend to be much more hysterical in my opinion actually -- about how it's all a massive hoax by some super-powerful shadow group, it's a fraud to sadistically take away freedom, put in place a one world government, destroy the economy, make us all slaves, etc etc. These claims are a lot more alarmist than anything I've ever seen in an IPCC report!  

So fine, forget the media and stick to the scientists. Yes this includes luke warmers like Curry and Michaels, but also the thousands who disagree with them and are concerned.
author: David

text: @David  Here's a specific reason I have a problem with the "alarmism". I am a professional forester with 47 years experience in Massachusetts. I do very good, careful, long term forest management. But, here in this state, the alarmists are so freaked out that they now are saying we should never, never, never cut any trees. But, with 7 billion people who want wood products- and given that wood products have a lower carbon footprint that cement, steel, plastic, etc.--- how will future generations have homes to live in, furniture and paper products?  Build cement homes? Plastic furniture? When done right- forest mgt. can produce wood while retaining much of the forest as it is- by means of light cutting, leaving the healthiest trees of the species best suited for the site and which can thence grow fastest to sequester the most carbon. But no, explaining that to these forestry haters doesn't work- they insist on stopping all tree cutting- and that has a lot of good forestry people royally pissed off. They claim all forestry destroys the forests and much "forestry" is poorly done- but there is such a thing as good forestry- but they persist in trying to get the state government to lock up all the forests. Of course THEY live in nice wood homes with wood furniture and paper products but they won't allow future generations to do the same. And, few are vegetarains (which I am)- when I ask them if they'll do that to lower their carbon footprint- and they mostly love to fly in jets, etc., etc. So I consider them hypocrites who want to wipe out the forestry folks while not willing to do their part. A lot of ordinary skeptics see this kind of craziness and hypocrisy. But we all know the climate is a bit warmer and that CO2 is a greenhouse gas- we just don't see evidence that it's an existential threat to the planet. What the alarmists call for is a drastic change of everything- and that's just not gonna happen without a civil war, which the alarmists will lose. They need to calm down a bit.

text: @Mr Brightside  Only when it combusts, not when it is converted by fungi and bacteria to organic molecules. I'm not arguing against trees, I am arguing for soil health.
author: Tony Blakeney

text: @Mr Brightside  I agree that we should build with wood, where possible. However, coal is combustible (even when it's underground), limestone is soluble, and both trees and wooden structures are susceptible to rot (and combustion). In the meantime, the soil NEEDS organic carbon to maintain fertility, retain structure, and store water. I'm not denying that carbon cycles through the atmosphere. However, we need a wide array of quick short-term and sustainable long-term approaches to tie up as much as possible of the carbon that has found its way (thanks to us) back into the atmosphere.
author: Tony Blakeney

text: @Mr Brightside  How on earth did you come up with that interpretation of what I am saying? No, both non-woody and woody plants absorb CO2 from the atmosphere. Fertile soil is alive with organisms that 'eat' organic compounds and the minerals they contain. Soils devoid of organic sources of carbon (and nitrogen) will not support plant life for long if farmers do not supplement the damage with energy-expensive chemicals---which leach into the environment, promoting toxic algal blooms. I'm NOT suggesting that we should NOT plant trees. I'm simply saying that we, as a species, ALSO need to 'feed' carbonaceous materials to the topsoils that have been damaged by poor management.

author: keir farnum

text:
@keir farnum  Ok let's talk about the efficiency of food production. I would argue that greenhouses use more resources, not less. The money, materials, labour, and pollution expended to make those greenhouses is definitely more than planting in an open field. 

I'm not aware of anyone growing corn, wheat, potatoes, or rice in greenhouses so I imagine that is not practical either. Remember that Dutch farmers are only able to get this process to work with the high value flowers, fruits, and vegetables? That's nice and all but most people get their calories from bread, rice and potatoes.

Yes less water is used per plant, but is fresh water that important a resource? Some places in the world do experience frequent droughts but surprise, surprise the parts of Earth where most food is grown don't have water problems. The Great Plains in North America, the European Plain, China, Argentina, and southern Brazil. While the places that do have a water problem usually wouldn't be helped by this technology. Proper desserts are too hot to grow anything. While underdeveloped nations like Ethiopia, which may experience droughts, don't have the human capital to operate this technology.

I would think it better to help these nations develop to the level of the first world. Support popular movements and governments that want to fight corruption and that respect property rights. This would allow locals to grow their own businesses and improve the economy and standard if living. Then education and foreign investment can be viable and there would be the money and human capital for your greenhouses. In the short term this would mean more pollution and forests being chopped down. But that's how you develop economics, you need to break a few eggs. Only rich nations whose people aren't suffering can afford to care about climate change.

Or we could keep treating other nations like orphaned children and pay their citizens pocket change to plant trees.

text: Listen to the other side of the argument, the climate change belief system is being perpetrated against you it’s been rammed down your throat. It is globalist bullshit to keep 3rd world countries in the 3rd world. The best climate for life is a warm climate with co2 at about 1000-2000 ppm so plant life can thrive. That is our history. The earth dies in the cold. Life dies in the cold. But carbon dioxide does not cause warming on any kind of catastrophic level, it is driven by over 100 other different variables, the biggest of which is the sun. Patrick Moore, Willie Soon, Peter Ridd, Judith Curry. These are your supposed enemies. Have you ever decided to listen to them and see whether the science actually pans out based on what they are saying? Don’t listen to the politicised rubbish coming from the left, we get it, orange man bad. If an issue becomes politicised you know it’s just about votes and they’ll tell you anything to get you on their side. They don’t care if you’re brainwashed by all this, the don’t care about anything except getting into power, least of all the truth in science.
